pullRequest.body: This PR removes the old `mergeSort'` in Mathlib (which was *not* a stable sort algorithm), replacing all uses with the stable `mergeSort` from Lean, mostly preserving the API.

`+ mergeSort_eq_self`
`- length_mergeSort'`
`- length_split_fst_le`

`- length_split_lt`

`- map_split`
`- mem_mergeSort'`

`- mergeSort'_singleton`

:v: kim-em can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).

As this PR is labelled `auto-merge-after-CI`, we are now sending it to bors:

bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11510341775/job/32041972164)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11510341775/job/32041971869)
I thought these comments were a cute demonstration of computability, I wouldn't want to see them go.

Can we turn this into an `example` instead?
We have more of such examples in mathlib...

```
unseal merge mergeSort in
example :
    mergeSort [5, 27, 221, 95, 17, 43, 7, 2, 98, 567, 23, 12] (fun m n => m / 10 ≤ n / 10) =
      [5, 7, 2, 17, 12, 27, 23, 43, 95, 98, 221, 567] := rfl
```      
One needs some `unseal`ing here to run the example by `rfl`.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - chore: cleanup of `mergeSort'`
